awd_titl_txt: Digitization TCN: Collaborative Research: The Key to the Cabinets: Building and Sustaining a Research Database for a Global Biodiversity Hotspot
awd_abstract_narration:
The southeastern USA is botanically rich, with areas of high global biodiversity in both the Appalachians and the coastal plain.  Millions of plant specimens have been collected from this region over the past four centuries, and these specimens and the information they contain currently reside in museums, or herbaria, at universities across the area.  Scientists study these specimens intently; however, it is difficult to retrieve information at broad geographic and taxonomic scales without pipelines to move the information electronically from the specimen to an accessible pool of data.  SERNEC, or the SouthEast Regional Network of Expertise and Collections, is a large regional network of botanical experts and collections that has, through an NSF-sponsored research coordination network (RCN) project, developed critical skills in biodiversity informatics.  The current project will allow the SERNEC group to make data available for over 3 million specimens using the latest photography and information capture tools and to engage citizen scientists and students to assist in transcribing and georeferencing this large dataset.  The research generated through this project can help regional planners, land managers and communities to manage their natural resources in our ever-changing environment.  

The interaction of scientists, citizen scientists, and students will provide a synergy to build a research tool of an unparalleled scale and scope.  The ultimate goal of this project is to develop an imaged and databased set of over 3 million specimens from over 100 herbaria in one of the most floristically diverse regions in North America and a global hotspot of plant diversity. This will represent a valuable data source for research on the response of vegetation to climate change, human development, and rapid migrations of introduced species. This region has been a biodiversity hotspot for 100 million years and this project should encourage research on changes over time to develop better predictive models as areas of biodiversity change. By partnering with Symbiota, Notes from Nature, GEOLocate, Adler Planetarium, iPlant/TACC, and Specify, the project will develop ways to best integrate various efforts for data accessibility. This award is made as part of the National Resource for Digitization of Biological Collections through the Advancing Digitization of Biological Collections program, and all data resulting from this award will be available through the national resource (iDigBio.org).

por.por_cntn:
Herbaria are plant museums.  Botanists have been making plant collections and putting them into herbaria for hundreds of years.  Each specimen is pressed flat, dried, and stored in metal cabinets to protect them from damage.  The specimen label has information about who collected the specimen, where and when it was collected, and the scientific name for the specimen.  Often label data will include information about the habitat or what other plants were found in the same locality. 

Herbaria range in size from a few million specimens in large research institutions to a few hundred specimens in teaching collections at colleges or state agencies.  Botanists have studied in herbaria for centuries, painstakingly taking specimens out of cabinets, studying, organizing and naming them.  Collectively, these specimens have tremendous value.  We can use herbarium specimens to determine plant distributions, flowering and fruiting times, both past and present.  The specimens can tell us about the presence and distribution of plant diseases and/or insect pests.  We can even retrieve DNA from specimens to understand plant relationships and lineages. 

We estimate there are about 900 herbaria in the USA that house approximately 90 million specimens.  This rich source of information about our natural history has been locked in herbaria and generally unavailable for broader study.  The project The Key to the Cabinets: Building and Sustaining a Research Database for a Global Biodiversity Hotspot, funded by the National Science Foundation (NSF Award 1410069), was designed to unlock those collections from the herbaria in the Southeast USA. 

We identified 235 herbaria in the Southeast USA that house 15 million specimens.  The curators of these collections have traditionally met at an annual regional meeting of the Association of Southeastern Biologists.  Early in the 21st century these curators formed the Society of Herbarium Curators, a group that now has national membership.  We developed a group called SERNEC (SouthEast Regional Network of Expertise and Collections) as a vehicle to support herbaria and we embarked on an effort to train ourselves in current museum digitization methods.  The name for our group, SERNEC, highlights the value of both the collections and the broad community of experts associated with the collections.

The Key to the Cabinets project was a regional effort to digitize 5 million specimens from species native to the Southeast USA and to make these collections available for teaching, research and as a learning tool for public.  We formed state level teams of curators, with Appalachian State University serving as the hub of the entire project and one institution in each state serving as a state-level organizing unit.  Ultimately, we involved 126 collections in this effort.  We purchased camera and lighting systems, sometimes shared among institutions, to photograph specimens and store them in the virtual CyVerse/TACC environment.  We helped develop the software tool Symbiota to upload these specimens to a virtual database that is accessible by the group.  Over the course of the project, we trained 1,355 students on best practices to image the specimens and to transcribe the label data from the specimens.  Transcribing label data is time consuming.  Since specimen labels are not standardized, the information must be typed by hand.  We collaborated with the Adler Museum and Notes from Nature, an NSF funded project that allows citizen scientists to assist in transcription efforts.  Through these efforts, we have transcribed 5,329,037 specimen labels and 4,855,573 (91%) of these have been imaged. 

The process of photographing specimens and transcribing label data enhances the specimen’s value to science and the public.  This value increases when we can pinpoint on a map where the specimen was collected.  This mapping process, called georeferencing, is also time consuming and requires expertise.  We were able to team with an NSF supported project called GEOLocate to develop strategies to automate some of this process.  Through the efforts of curators, students and the public, we have now georeferenced 762,096 specimens. 

The virtual communication and software environment developed in this project has united the curators and affiliate scientists in our efforts to protect, enhance and utilize the specimens housed in the 235 collections in the Southeast.  The development of these tools and the support for the community of scientists provides the infrastructure needed to continue our efforts.  We plan to continue this project and fully digitize the 15 million specimens housed in herbaria throughout the region.

The Southeast USA is one of the most biodiverse regions of the world and is very worthy of study.  The Key to the Cabinets project has built a sustainable infrastructure to unlock our herbarium collections and make them available for study and learning.  We believe the human infrastructure and the dynamic database we have created, coupled with the software tools and technical expertise, will continue to be of benefit to the scientific community and to the public.
